notes:
1. Definition

Differential leveling is the most common method of leveling used by surveyors to determine the difference in elevation between two points. It involves using a surveying instrument called a level, which establishes a horizontal line of sight, and a graduated leveling rod.

2. Basic Procedure

The process involves a series of instrument setups and readings:

  1. Set up the level at a location where you can see a point of known elevation (a benchmark, BM) and a point of unknown elevation.
  2. Take a reading on the leveling rod held on the benchmark. This reading is called a backsight (BS).
  3. Calculate the Height of Instrument (HI). This is the elevation of the horizontal line of sight.
    4. $$ HI = Elevation_{BM} + BS $$
  4. Move the rod to a point of unknown elevation and take a reading. This is a foresight (FS).
  5. Calculate the elevation of the new point.
    6. $$ Elevation_{New Point} = HI - FS $$

This process can be repeated by moving the instrument, using the new point as a turning point (TP) to establish a new HI.

3. Field Notes and Checks

Surveyors keep meticulous field notes in a table format. A common arithmetic check is to ensure that the sum of all backsights minus the sum of all foresights equals the difference between the starting and ending elevations.

$$ \sum BS - \sum FS = Elevation_{End} - Elevation_{Start} $$

solvedExamples.question: A surveyor sets up a level and takes a backsight reading of 4.52 ft on a benchmark with an elevation of 100.00 ft. What is the Height of Instrument (HI)?
solvedExamples.explanation: The Height of Instrument is the elevation of the known point plus the backsight reading. $HI = Elevation + BS = 100.00 \text{ ft} + 4.52 \text{ ft} = 104.52$ ft.

solvedExamples.question: From the same instrument setup (HI = 104.52 ft), the surveyor takes a foresight reading of 6.89 ft on a new point. What is the elevation of the new point?
solvedExamples.explanation: The elevation of a new point is the Height of Instrument minus the foresight reading. $Elevation = HI - FS = 104.52 \text{ ft} - 6.89 \text{ ft} = 97.63$ ft.
